property.configure: The input sof

property.name: description
property.configure: null

property.name: author
property.configure: Steve Neuendorffer

property.name: version
property.configure: null

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
The BooleanSwitch actor reads a value of any type, as well as a Boolean token that is used as a control. If the Boolean token is true, the actor outputs the received value to the trueOutput port; if the Boolean token is false, the actor outputs the received value to the falseOutput port. If the actor has never received a value on the control port, then the actor will output to the falseOutput port.

The actor only works under certain directors. It will not work under an SDF Director, but it will under a PN Director, for example.

property.name: port:input
property.configure: An input port that accepts tokens of any type.

property.name: port:falseOutput
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts the input token when the control is false.

property.name: port:trueOutput
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts the input token when the control is true.

property.name: port:control
property.configure: An input port that accepts a Boolean token used to select which output port (trueOutput or falseOutput) to broadcast.

property.name: description
property.configure: null

property.name: author
property.configure: Edward Lee

property.name: version
property.configure: null

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
The StringConstant actor outputs a string specified via the actor's value parameter.

Specifying strings with the StringConstant actor is convenient, as the actor does not require that strings be surrounded by quotes. The actor is often used to specify file paths, which can be selected using the Browse button available in the actor's parameters.

Specified string values can include references to parameters within scope (i.e., parameters defined at the same level of the hierarchy or higher).

NOTE: If using a PN Director, the 'firingCountLimit' parameter is often set to a finite integer (e.g. '1') so that the workflow will terminate.

property.name: port:output
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts a string constant specified by the value parameter.

property.name: port:trigger
property.configure: A multiport that has no declared type (in other words, the port can accept any data type: double, int, array, etc.) If the port is connected, the actor will not fire until the trigger port receives an input token. Connecting the port is optional, but useful when scheduling the actor to perform at a certain time.

property.name: prop:firingCountLimit
property.configure: The limit on the number of times the actor will fire. The default value is 'NONE', meaning there is no limit on the number of time the constant will be provided to the output port. Any integer can be provided as a value for this parameter.

property.name: prop:value
property.configure: The value produced by the actor. Specified strings do not require enclosing quotes. (To include a '$' sign in the string, enter '$$'.)

property.name: description
property.configure: null

property.name: author
property.configure: Gang Zhou

property.name: version
property.configure: null

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
A type polymorphic select with boolean valued control for use in the DDF domain. In the first iteration, an input token at the control port is read and its value is noted. In the second iteration, if the control input read from the previous iteration is true, then an input token at the trueInput port is read and sent to the output. Likewise with a false control input and the falseInput port. It alternates between these two kinds of iterations until stopped. The control port must receive Boolean Tokens. The trueInput and falseInput ports may receive Tokens of any type. Because tokens are immutable, the same Token is sent to the output, rather than a copy.

Note this actor sends an output token every two iterations. Contrast this with BooleanSelect which sends an output token every iteration.

property.name: port:falseInput
property.configure: Input for tokens on the false path. The port type can be any type.

property.name: port:output
property.configure: The output port. The type is at least the type of trueInput and falseInput.

property.name: port:trueInput
property.configure: Input for tokens on the true path. The port type can be any type.

property.name: port:control
property.configure: Input that selects one of the other input ports. The type is boolean.

property.name: description
property.configure: It reads the content of a directory and creates an SoF

property.name: author
property.configure: ESO

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure: The SofCreator reads the contents of a directory and creates an SoF: the file category is based on the keyword PRO.CATG or REFLEX.CATG. If both are missing the Default Category is used.

property.name: port:data dir
property.configure: The input dir. If an empty string is provided the actor generates an empty SoF

property.name: port:sof out
property.configure: The output sof

property.name: prop:Filename Pattern
property.configure: a wildcard pattern representing the files to be included (e.g. *.fits)

property.name: prop:Default Category
property.configure: The default category to be used if none is defined in the file.

property.name: description
property.configure: null

property.name: author
property.configure: ESO

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
The SofSplitter takes a set of files as input and split it into smaller sets, grouping them by purpose. Files with universal purpose are attached to every subset. This smaller sets can then be sent to e.g. a RecipeExecuter.

Example: Consider the following SoF as input:

SoF IN: File1(Purpose1), File2(Purpose2), File3(Purpose3), File4(Purpose2), File5(Purpose3),File6(UNIVERSAL)

In this case the SofSplitter generates the following SoFs as output:

SoF1: File1(Purpose1), File6(Purpose1)

SoF2: File2(Purpose2), File4(Purpose2), File6(Purpose2)

SoF3: File3(Purpose3), File5(Purpose3), File6(Purpose3)

property.name: port:#groups
property.configure: The number of groups generated

property.name: port:sof out
property.configure: The grouped sofs

property.name: description
property.configure: null

property.name: author
property.configure: ESO

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure: This actor is usually used together with the SofSplitter, and it puts back together in a single set of files the tokens generated by SofSplitter (and usually processed by the RecipeExecuter). It can also be used to accumulate, for instance, SoFs coming from different OBs to compose a mosaic. The actor collects a number of tokens from every input port and simply appends all the files to generate one SoF, that is than sent to the output port.

property.name: port:sof in
property.configure: The input sofs

property.name: port:#groups

property.name: author

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
The FitsRouter sorts files based on their category: by default, all files are routed to the rejected directory, but the user can add an additional port and configure the actor to route particular files to the new port. The category is defined by the value of either HIERARCH.ESO.PRO.CATG (keyword added to the file by the pipeline recipes) or REFLEX.CATG (virtual keyword created by the DataOrganizer).

Basic Mode: create an output port named as a category (e.g.: FLAT), all files belonging to that category will be routed to that port.

Advanced Mode: create an output port named as you want (e.g.: MyPort), then create a string parameter whose name is the port name plus "_config" (e.g.: MyPort_config). This parameter can be a list of regular expressions separated by a comma or a space (you can mix both in the same parameter): each file matching at least one of them will be routed to this port.

If you want to define the minimum or maximum the number of files that are broadcasted to a port you can define a parameter whose name is the port name plus "_min_number" or "_max_number", respectively.

Note: one file can be routed to many ports, if no port fits it is routed to the rejected port.

property.configure: The input sof

property.name: author
property.configure: ESO

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
The SofCombiner takes as input a number of set of files and combines them into one set of files that contains only the files whose purposes are present in all the input tokens. With this respect empty tokens are ignored and files with universal purpose are always collected.

For example, consider the following SoFs:

SoF1: File1(Purpose1), File2(Purpose2), File3(Purpose3)

SoF2: File4(Purpose2), File5(Purpose3), File6(Purpose4), File7(UNIVERSAL)

SoF3:

SoF4: File8(Purpose2), File9(Purpose5), File10(Purpose6)

SoF5: File11(Purpose2), File12(Purpose3), File13(Purpose7)

SoF6:

SoF7: File14(UNIVERSAL)

If SoF 1-3 are connected to sof in and the SoF 4-7 are connected to sof opt in, then the output SoF will be:

File2(Purpose2), File3(Purpose3)

File4(Purpose2), File5(Purpose3), File7(Purpose2,Purpose3)

File8(Purpose2)

File11(Purpose2), File12(Purpose3)

File14(Purpose2,Purpose3)

Note: all input multi ports that take SoF as input (e.g. in the RecipeExecuter) behave like the SofCombiner with no optional inputs

property.name: port:sof in opt
property.configure: The optional input sofs, these files are added to the output only if their purpose is present in one of the input SoFs

property.name: port:sof in
property.configure: The input sofs

property.name: port:sof out
property.configure: The combined sof

property.name: prop:IgnorePurpose
property.configure: if true, the input SoFs will be combined regardless of the purposes.

The StringConstant actor outputs a string specified via the actor's value parameter.

Specifying strings with the StringConstant actor is convenient, as the actor does not require that strings be surrounded by quotes. The actor is often used to specify file paths, which can be selected using the Browse button available in the actor's parameters.

Specified string values can include references to parameters within scope (i.e., parameters defined at the same level of the hierarchy or higher).

NOTE: If using a PN Director, the 'firingCountLimit' parameter is often set to a finite integer (e.g. '1') so that the workflow will terminate.

property.name: port:output
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts a string constant specified by the value parameter.

property.name: port:trigger
property.configure: A multiport that has no declared type (in other words, the port can accept any data type: double, int, array, etc.) If the port is connected, the actor will not fire until the trigger port receives an input token. Connecting the port is optional, but useful when scheduling the actor to perform at a certain time.

property.name: prop:firingCountLimit
property.configure: The limit on the number of times the actor will fire. The default value is 'NONE', meaning there is no limit on the number of time the constant will be provided to the output port. Any integer can be provided as a value for this parameter.

property.name: prop:value
property.configure: The value produced by the actor. Specified strings do not require enclosing quotes. (To include a '$' sign in the string, enter '$$'.)

property.name: description
property.configure: null

property.name: author
property.configure: Edward Lee

property.name: version
property.configure: null

property.name: userLevelDocumentation

property.name: prop:firingCountLimit

property.name: prop:value
property.configure: The value produced by the actor. Specified strings do not require enclosing quotes. (To include a '$' sign in the string, enter '$$'.)

property.name: description
property.configure: null

property.name: author
property.configure: Vinay Krishnan, Daniel Lazaro Cuadrado (contributor: Edward A. Lee)

property.name: version
property.configure: null

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
The StringCompare actor reads two strings and compares them using a specified comparison function. The actor outputs true if the strings satisfy the comparison criteria, or false if not.

The comparison functions are specified with the function parameter:

  • equals: Output true if the strings are equal (the default).
  • startsWith: Output true if the first string starts with second string.
  • endsWith: Output true if the first string ends with the second string.
  • contains: Output true if the first string contains the second string.

Strings will be read from the input ports if they are connected; otherwise strings are read from the parameters.

property.name: port:secondString
property.configure: An input port that accepts the second string.

property.name: port:output
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts the result of the comparison (either true or false).

property.name: port:firstString
property.configure: An input port that accepts the first string.

property.name: prop:function
property.configure: The comparison function (equals, startsWith, endsWith, contains). The default is "equals".

property.name: prop:secondString
property.configure: The second string.

property.name: prop:ignoreCase
property.configure: Specify whether to ignore case. By default, the actor is case-sensitive. Select the parameter to ignore case.

property.name: prop:firstString
property.configure: The first string.

property.name: description
property.configure: null

property.name: author
property.configure: Steve Neuendorffer

property.name: version
property.configure: null

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
The BooleanSwitch actor reads a value of any type, as well as a Boolean token that is used as a control. If the Boolean token is true, the actor outputs the received value to the trueOutput port; if the Boolean token is false, the actor outputs the received value to the falseOutput port. If the actor has never received a value on the control port, then the actor will output to the falseOutput port.

The actor only works under certain directors. It will not work under an SDF Director, but it will under a PN Director, for example.

property.name: port:input
property.configure: An input port that accepts tokens of any type.

property.name: port:falseOutput
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts the input token when the control is false.

property.name: port:trueOutput
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts the input token when the control is true.

property.name: port:control
property.configure: An input port that accepts a Boolean token used to select which output port (trueOutput or falseOutput) to broadcast.

property.name: description
property.configure: null

property.name: author
property.configure: Gang Zhou

property.name: version
property.configure: null

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
A type polymorphic select with boolean valued control for use in the DDF domain. In the first iteration, an input token at the control port is read and its value is noted. In the second iteration, if the control input read from the previous iteration is true, then an input token at the trueInput port is read and sent to the output. Likewise with a false control input and the falseInput port. It alternates between these two kinds of iterations until stopped. The control port must receive Boolean Tokens. The trueInput and falseInput ports may receive Tokens of any type. Because tokens are immutable, the same Token is sent to the output, rather than a copy.

Note this actor sends an output token every two iterations. Contrast this with BooleanSelect which sends an output token every iteration.

property.name: port:falseInput
property.configure: Input for tokens on the false path. The port type can be any type.

property.name: port:output
property.configure: The output port. The type is at least the type of trueInput and falseInput.

property.name: port:trueInput
property.configure: Input for tokens on the true path. The port type can be any type.

property.name: port:control
property.configure: Input that selects one of the other input ports. The type is boolean.

property.name: description
property.configure: null

property.name: author
property.configure: Edward Lee

property.name: version
property.configure: null

property.name: userLevelDocumentation

property.name: description
property.configure: It reads the content of a directory and creates an SoF

property.name: author
property.configure: ESO

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure: The SofCreator reads the contents of a directory and creates an SoF: the file category is based on the keyword PRO.CATG or REFLEX.CATG. If both are missing the Default Category is used.

property.name: port:data dir
property.configure: The input dir. If an empty string is provided the actor generates an empty SoF

property.name: port:sof out
property.configure: The output sof

property.name: prop:Filename Pattern
property.configure: a wildcard pattern representing the files to be included (e.g. *.fits)

property.name: prop:Default Category
property.configure: The default category to be used if none is defined in the file.

property.name: description
property.configure: null

property.name: author
property.configure: Gang Zhou

property.name: version
property.configure: null

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
The dynamic dataflow (DDF) domain is a superset of the synchronous dataflow(SDF) and Boolean dataflow(BDF) domains. In the SDF domain, an actor consumes and produces a fixed number of tokens per firing. This static information makes possible compile-time scheduling. In the DDF domain, there are few constraints on the production and consumption behavior of actors, and the schedulers make no attempt to construct a compile-time schedule. Instead, each actor has a set of firing rules (patterns) and can be fired if one of them is satisfied, i.e., one particular firing pattern forms a prefix of sequences of unconsumed tokens at input ports. The canonical actors in the DDF domain include Select and Switch, which consume or produce tokens on different channels based on the token received from the control port. (In practice, use DDFSelect and DDFBooleanSelect in the DDF-specific library instead of Select and BooleanSelect in the regular FlowControl library; however, Switch and BooleanSwitch in the regular FlowControl library can be used in DDF domain.)

The dynamic scheduler implemented in this director fires all enabled and non-deferrable actors once in a basic iteration. A deferrable actor is one that will not help one of the downstream actors become enabled because that downstream actor either already has enough tokens on the channel connecting those two actors or is waiting for tokens on another channel. If no actor fires so far, which means there is no enabled and non-deferrable actor, then among all enabled and deferrable actors, this director fires those which have the smallest maximum number of tokens on their output channels which satisfy the demand of destination actors. If still no actor fires, then there is no enabled actor. A user can treat several such basic iterations as a single iteration by adding a parameter with name requiredFiringsPerIteration to an actor (which is often a sink actor or an actor directly connected to output port of the composite actor) and specifying the number of times this actor must be fired in a single iteration. If the value of the parameter runUntilDeadlockInOneIteration is a BooleanToken with value true, one single iteration consists of repeating the basic iteration until deadlock is reached (thus overriding the previous definition of one iteration), which is the status of the model where all active actors under the control of this director are unable to fire because their firing rules are not satisfied. However, they may be able to fire again during next iteration when tokens are transferred in from an outside domain. Note runUntilDeadlockInOneIteration can be set to true only when this director is not on the top level.

The algorithm implementing one basic iteration goes like this: 

            E = set of enabled actors
            D = set of deferrable enabled actors
One basic(default) iteration consists of: 
            if (E\D != empty set) {
            fire (E\D)
            } else if (D != empty set) {
            fire minimax(D)
            } else {
            declare deadlock
            }
The function "minimax(D)" returns a subset of D with the smallest maximum number of tokens on their output channels which satisfy the demand of destination actors.

Note that any SDF model can be run with a DDF Director. However, the notion of iteration is different. One could try to imitate the SDF iteration in the DDF domain by controlling the number of firings in one iteration for some actors, such as requiring a plotter to plot a fixed number of points in each iteration.

In the DDF domain, the firing rule of any actor is specified by the token consumption rates of its input ports. A general DDF actor could change the consumption rates of its input ports after each firing of this actor. For multiports, an array token could be used to specify different rates for different channels connected to the same multiport. Note that in SDF, all channels connected to the same multiport have the same rate.

Based on DDFSimpleSched in Ptolemy Classic, by Edward Lee. See E. A. Lee et al., "The Almagest," documentation for Ptolemy Classic, Vol. 1, Chapter 7, 1997.

property.name: prop:iterations
property.configure: Specify the number of times a workflow is iterated. By default, this parameter is set to "0". Note that "0" does not mean "no iterations." Rather, "0" means that the workflow will iterate forever. Values greater than zero specify the actual number of times the director should execute the entire workflow.

property.name: prop:maximumReceiverCapacity
property.configure: A Parameter representing the maximum capacity of each receiver controlled by this director. This is an integer that defaults to 0, which means the queue in each receiver is unbounded. To specify bounded queues, set this to a positive integer.

property.name: prop:runUntilDeadlockInOneIteration
property.configure: A parameter indicating whether one iteration consists of repeated basic iterations until deadlock. If this parameter is true, the model will be executed until deadlock in one iteration. The default value is a BooleanToken with the value false. It cannot be set to true if this director is at the top level.

property.name: description
property.configure: Identifies empty SoFs

property.name: author
property.configure: ESO

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure: IsSofEmpty emits a true token if the input soF is empty

property.name: port:is empty
property.configure: true if the input is empty

property.name: port:sof in
property.configure: The input sof

property.name: value
property.value: Warning: DARK frames are present in the dataset, however the muse_dark recipe is disabled. The use of DARK frames is not recommended for data reduction, as it will introduce noise in your final product. If you really want to use DARK frames in you reduction: - stop the workflow. - open the "Master Dark" actor (right mouse button, and select "Open Actor") - localize the muse_dark_1 actor and double click on it - Set the recipe mode to "run" (default: disabled) - restart the workflow.

property.name: _windowProperties
property.value: {bounds={0, 535, 640, 403}, maximized=false}

property.name: description
property.configure: null

property.name: author
property.configure: Yuhong Xiong, Edward A. Lee

property.name: version
property.configure: null

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
The Display actor reads tokens of any type via its input multiport, and displays each token on a separate line in a text display window.

Specify the size of the text display window with the rowsDisplayed and columnsDisplayed parameters. Simply resizing the window onscreen does not persistently change the size when the workflow is saved, closed, and then re-opened.

If the input is a string token, then the actor strips the surrounding quotation marks before displaying the value.

Select the suppressBlankLines parameter to specify that the actor not add blank lines to the display. By default, the actor will add blank lines.

Note: this actor can consume large amounts of memory. It is not advisable to use it to display large output streams.

property.name: port:input
property.configure: A multiport that accepts tokens of any type.

property.name: prop:suppressBlankLines
property.configure: Specify whether the actor should display blank lines (the default) or suppress them.

property.name: prop:rowsDisplayed
property.configure: The vertical size of the display, in rows. The value is an integer that defaults to 10.

property.name: prop:columnsDisplayed
property.configure: The horizontal size of the display, in columns. The value is an integer that defaults to 40.

property.name: prop:title
property.configure: The title of the text display window. If specified, the value will appear in the title bar of the text display window.

property.name: description
property.configure: null

property.name: author
property.configure: Steve Neuendorffer

property.name: version

property.name: description
property.configure: null

property.name: author
property.configure: Vinay Krishnan, Daniel Lazaro Cuadrado (contributor: Edward A. Lee)

property.name: version
property.configure: null

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
The StringCompare actor reads two strings and compares them using a specified comparison function. The actor outputs true if the strings satisfy the comparison criteria, or false if not.

The comparison functions are specified with the function parameter:

  • equals: Output true if the strings are equal (the default).
  • startsWith: Output true if the first string starts with second string.
  • endsWith: Output true if the first string ends with the second string.
  • contains: Output true if the first string contains the second string.

Strings will be read from the input ports if they are connected; otherwise strings are read from the parameters.

property.name: port:secondString
property.configure: An input port that accepts the second string.

property.name: port:output
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts the result of the comparison (either true or false).

property.name: port:firstString
property.configure: An input port that accepts the first string.

property.name: prop:function
property.configure: The comparison function (equals, startsWith, endsWith, contains). The default is "equals".

property.name: prop:secondString
property.configure: The second string.

property.name: prop:ignoreCase
property.configure: Specify whether to ignore case. By default, the actor is case-sensitive. Select the parameter to ignore case.

property.name: prop:firstString
property.configure: The first string.

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
The Display actor reads tokens of any type via its input multiport, and displays each token on a separate line in a text display window.

Specify the size of the text display window with the rowsDisplayed and columnsDisplayed parameters. Simply resizing the window onscreen does not persistently change the size when the workflow is saved, closed, and then re-opened.

If the input is a string token, then the actor strips the surrounding quotation marks before displaying the value.

Select the suppressBlankLines parameter to specify that the actor not add blank lines to the display. By default, the actor will add blank lines.

Note: this actor can consume large amounts of memory. It is not advisable to use it to display large output streams.

property.name: port:input
property.configure: A multiport that accepts tokens of any type.

property.name: prop:suppressBlankLines
property.configure: Specify whether the actor should display blank lines (the default) or suppress them.

property.name: prop:rowsDisplayed
property.configure: The vertical size of the display, in rows. The value is an integer that defaults to 10.

property.name: prop:columnsDisplayed
property.configure: The horizontal size of the display, in columns. The value is an integer that defaults to 40.

property.name: prop:title
property.configure: The title of the text display window. If specified, the value will appear in the title bar of the text display window.

property.name: description
property.configure: null

property.name: author
property.configure: Gang Zhou

property.name: version
property.configure: null

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
A type polymorphic select with boolean valued control for use in the DDF domain. In the first iteration, an input token at the control port is read and its value is noted. In the second iteration, if the control input read from the previous iteration is true, then an input token at the trueInput port is read and sent to the output. Likewise with a false control input and the falseInput port. It alternates between these two kinds of iterations until stopped. The control port must receive Boolean Tokens. The trueInput and falseInput ports may receive Tokens of any type. Because tokens are immutable, the same Token is sent to the output, rather than a copy.

Note this actor sends an output token every two iterations. Contrast this with BooleanSelect which sends an output token every iteration.

property.name: port:falseInput
property.configure: Input for tokens on the false path. The port type can be any type.

property.name: port:output
property.configure: The output port. The type is at least the type of trueInput and falseInput.

property.name: port:trueInput
property.configure: Input for tokens on the true path. The port type can be any type.

property.name: port:control
property.configure: Input that selects one of the other input ports. The type is boolean.

property.name: description
property.configure: null

property.name: author
property.configure: Yuhong Xiong

property.name: version
property.configure: null

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
A Composite actor is an aggregation of actors. It may have a local director that is responsible for executing the contained actors. A Composite actor with a local director is called an opaque actor. Composite actors do not require a local director. Composite actors with no local director "inherit" the director from the containing workflow and are called non-opaque.

To create a composite actor, drag and drop the Composite actor onto the Workflow canvas. Right-click the actor and select Open Actor from the drop-down menu. A new Kepler application window will open for designing the composite.

property.value:
A Composite actor is an aggregation of actors. It may have a local director that is responsible for executing the contained actors. A Composite actor with a local director is called an opaque actor. Composite actors do not require a local director. Composite actors with no local director "inherit" the director from the containing workflow and are called non-opaque.

To create a composite actor, drag and drop the Composite actor onto the Workflow canvas. Right-click the actor and select Open Actor from the drop-down menu. A new Kepler application window will open for designing the composite.

property.name: author
property.value: Yuhong Xiong

property.name: description
property.configure: null

property.name: author
property.configure: Gang Zhou

property.name: version
property.configure: null

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
The dynamic dataflow (DDF) domain is a superset of the synchronous dataflow(SDF) and Boolean dataflow(BDF) domains. In the SDF domain, an actor consumes and produces a fixed number of tokens per firing. This static information makes possible compile-time scheduling. In the DDF domain, there are few constraints on the production and consumption behavior of actors, and the schedulers make no attempt to construct a compile-time schedule. Instead, each actor has a set of firing rules (patterns) and can be fired if one of them is satisfied, i.e., one particular firing pattern forms a prefix of sequences of unconsumed tokens at input ports. The canonical actors in the DDF domain include Select and Switch, which consume or produce tokens on different channels based on the token received from the control port. (In practice, use DDFSelect and DDFBooleanSelect in the DDF-specific library instead of Select and BooleanSelect in the regular FlowControl library; however, Switch and BooleanSwitch in the regular FlowControl library can be used in DDF domain.)

The dynamic scheduler implemented in this director fires all enabled and non-deferrable actors once in a basic iteration. A deferrable actor is one that will not help one of the downstream actors become enabled because that downstream actor either already has enough tokens on the channel connecting those two actors or is waiting for tokens on another channel. If no actor fires so far, which means there is no enabled and non-deferrable actor, then among all enabled and deferrable actors, this director fires those which have the smallest maximum number of tokens on their output channels which satisfy the demand of destination actors. If still no actor fires, then there is no enabled actor. A user can treat several such basic iterations as a single iteration by adding a parameter with name requiredFiringsPerIteration to an actor (which is often a sink actor or an actor directly connected to output port of the composite actor) and specifying the number of times this actor must be fired in a single iteration. If the value of the parameter runUntilDeadlockInOneIteration is a BooleanToken with value true, one single iteration consists of repeating the basic iteration until deadlock is reached (thus overriding the previous definition of one iteration), which is the status of the model where all active actors under the control of this director are unable to fire because their firing rules are not satisfied. However, they may be able to fire again during next iteration when tokens are transferred in from an outside domain. Note runUntilDeadlockInOneIteration can be set to true only when this director is not on the top level.

The algorithm implementing one basic iteration goes like this: 

            E = set of enabled actors
            D = set of deferrable enabled actors
One basic(default) iteration consists of: 
            if (E\D != empty set) {
            fire (E\D)
            } else if (D != empty set) {
            fire minimax(D)
            } else {
            declare deadlock
            }
The function "minimax(D)" returns a subset of D with the smallest maximum number of tokens on their output channels which satisfy the demand of destination actors.

Note that any SDF model can be run with a DDF Director. However, the notion of iteration is different. One could try to imitate the SDF iteration in the DDF domain by controlling the number of firings in one iteration for some actors, such as requiring a plotter to plot a fixed number of points in each iteration.

In the DDF domain, the firing rule of any actor is specified by the token consumption rates of its input ports. A general DDF actor could change the consumption rates of its input ports after each firing of this actor. For multiports, an array token could be used to specify different rates for different channels connected to the same multiport. Note that in SDF, all channels connected to the same multiport have the same rate.

Based on DDFSimpleSched in Ptolemy Classic, by Edward Lee. See E. A. Lee et al., "The Almagest," documentation for Ptolemy Classic, Vol. 1, Chapter 7, 1997.

property.name: prop:iterations
property.configure: Specify the number of times a workflow is iterated. By default, this parameter is set to "0". Note that "0" does not mean "no iterations." Rather, "0" means that the workflow will iterate forever. Values greater than zero specify the actual number of times the director should execute the entire workflow.

property.name: prop:maximumReceiverCapacity
property.configure: A Parameter representing the maximum capacity of each receiver controlled by this director. This is an integer that defaults to 0, which means the queue in each receiver is unbounded. To specify bounded queues, set this to a positive integer.

property.name: prop:runUntilDeadlockInOneIteration
property.configure: A parameter indicating whether one iteration consists of repeated basic iterations until deadlock. If this parameter is true, the model will be executed until deadlock in one iteration. The default value is a BooleanToken with the value false. It cannot be set to true if this director is at the top level.

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
The RecipeExecuter executes one CPL recipe. The recipe can be chosen only when you instantiate the component: at the moment the user is presented with a list of the available recipes (the output of esorex --recipes). After the user selects the recipe the actor queries EsoRex for the recipe parameters and adds them to the actor. Each parameter is set to the default value: if the user wants to change any of the parameters then he can enter his own value or he can write the special value PORT, in which case the value is taken from the input port SoP.

The actor has three modes: Run, Skip and Disabled

Note: since this actor has very different behaviour depending on the pipeline recipe to which it is associated, it is not present in the left hand side actor list, and instead it must be instantiated from the menu.

property.name: port:sop in
property.configure: the recipe input parameters

property.name: port:rejected outputs
property.configure: the outputs not matching any of the output categories

property.name: port:logs
property.configure: the logs generated by EsoRex, empty if lazy mode is triggered

property.name: port:rejected inputs
property.configure: the inputs not matching any of the input categories

property.name: port:warnings
property.configure: the warnings generated by EsoRex, empty if lazy mode is triggered

property.name: port:sof in
property.configure: the input files

property.name: port:sof out
property.configure: the output files

property.name: port:errors
property.configure: the errors generated by EsoRex, empty if lazy mode is triggered

property.name: port:sop out
property.configure: the parameters used in the last execution of the recipe

property.name: prop:Input Files Category
property.configure: a list of file categories separated by a comma or a space: only input files belonging to one of these categories will be passed to the recipe

property.name: prop:recipe
property.configure: the selected pipeline recipe (cannot be changed)

property.name: prop:Output Files Category
property.configure: a list of file categories separated by a comma or a space: only products belonging to one of these categories will be broadcast to the output port

property.name: prop:Pause before execution
property.configure: if true then the execution is paused just before executing the recipe

property.name: prop:Bookkeeping Dir
property.configure: the directory the recipe will use as a working directory

property.name: prop:Clean Temporary Directories
property.configure: if true, the temporary directories (where the logs, the final and the temporary products of the recipe are created) are cleaned before the execution

property.name: prop:Lazy Mode
property.configure: if true then the actor will check whether the pipeline recipe has already been executed with the same input files and with the same recipe parameters. If this is the case then the recipe will not be executed, and instead the previously generated products (which are the same as those that would have been generated if the recipe were executed, except for a timestamp) will be broadcast to the output port.

property.name: prop:mode
property.configure:
Run: the recipe will be executed (see lazy mode)

Skip: the inputs are broadcast to the output with the following modifications: input files will be filtered according to input and output tags and recipe parameters will be filtered based on the recipe and whether the parameter is set to PORT

Disabled: the recipe is not executed and an empty SoF is generated on the output port

property.name: prop:File Purpose Processing
property.configure:
how the purpose of the input files will be sent to the output:

Do nothing: leave the input purpose unmodified

Strip last: remove the last section of the input purpose, if there is only one section set the purpose to universal. This is the default mode, and it means that the actor has completed a reduction step and removes it from the purpose chain

Set to universal: set the output purpose to universal

property.configure: Parameter name: nkeep. Default value:1

property.name: prop:recipe_param_8
property.configure: Parameter name: nhigh. Default value:1

property.name: prop:Logs Dir
property.configure: the directory where the EsoRex logs will be saved

property.name: prop:recipe_param_7
property.configure: Parameter name: nlow. Default value:1

property.name: prop:recipe_param_6
property.configure: Parameter name: combine. Default value:sigclip

property.name: prop:recipe_param_5
property.configure: Parameter name: ovscignore. Default value:3

property.name: prop:recipe_param_4
property.configure: Parameter name: ovscsigma. Default value:30

property.name: prop:Products Dir
property.configure: the directory where the products will be created

property.name: prop:recipe_param_3
property.configure: Parameter name: ovscreject. Default value:dcr

property.name: prop:recipe_param_2
property.configure: Parameter name: overscan. Default value:vpoly

property.name: prop:recipe_param_1
property.configure: Parameter name: nifu. Default value:0

property.name: prop:Recipe Failure Mode
property.configure:
it specifies the behavior of the actor if the recipe fails

Stop: the actor produces an error message and the workflows stops. This is the default

Continue: the actor outputs an empty SoF

Ask: the actor pops up a window and asks the user whether he wants to continue or stop the execution

property.name: prop:EsoRex default args
property.configure: additional parameters passed to EsoRex

property.name: prop:recipe_param_14
property.configure: Parameter name: merge. Default value:false

property.configure: Parameter name: hisigmabadpix. Default value:3

property.name: prop:recipe_param_12

property.name: prop:recipe_param_11
property.configure: Parameter name: hsigma. Default value:3

property.name: prop:recipe_param_10
property.configure: Parameter name: lsigma. Default value:3

property.name: prop:Pause after execution
property.configure: if true then the execution is paused after the execution of the recipe

property.name: prop:Allow empty inputs
property.configure: if true then an empty sof on the input port will be broadcast to the output without executing the recipe

property.name: description
property.configure: null

property.name: author
property.configure: ESO

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
The FitsRouter sorts files based on their category: by default, all files are routed to the rejected directory, but the user can add an additional port and configure the actor to route particular files to the new port. The category is defined by the value of either HIERARCH.ESO.PRO.CATG (keyword added to the file by the pipeline recipes) or REFLEX.CATG (virtual keyword created by the DataOrganizer).

Basic Mode: create an output port named as a category (e.g.: FLAT), all files belonging to that category will be routed to that port.

Advanced Mode: create an output port named as you want (e.g.: MyPort), then create a string parameter whose name is the port name plus "_config" (e.g.: MyPort_config). This parameter can be a list of regular expressions separated by a comma or a space (you can mix both in the same parameter): each file matching at least one of them will be routed to this port.

If you want to define the minimum or maximum the number of files that are broadcasted to a port you can define a parameter whose name is the port name plus "_min_number" or "_max_number", respectively.

Note: one file can be routed to many ports, if no port fits it is routed to the rejected port.

property.configure: The input data

property.configure: The rejected SoF

property.configure: Steve Neuendorffer

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
The BooleanSwitch actor reads a value of any type, as well as a Boolean token that is used as a control. If the Boolean token is true, the actor outputs the received value to the trueOutput port; if the Boolean token is false, the actor outputs the received value to the falseOutput port. If the actor has never received a value on the control port, then the actor will output to the falseOutput port.

The actor only works under certain directors. It will not work under an SDF Director, but it will under a PN Director, for example.

property.name: port:input
property.configure: An input port that accepts tokens of any type.

property.name: port:falseOutput
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts the input token when the control is false.

property.name: port:trueOutput
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts the input token when the control is true.

property.name: port:control
property.configure: An input port that accepts a Boolean token used to select which output port (trueOutput or falseOutput) to broadcast.

property.configure: null

property.name: author
property.configure: Gang Zhou

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
A type polymorphic select with boolean valued control for use in the DDF domain. In the first iteration, an input token at the control port is read and its value is noted. In the second iteration, if the control input read from the previous iteration is true, then an input token at the trueInput port is read and sent to the output. Likewise with a false control input and the falseInput port. It alternates between these two kinds of iterations until stopped. The control port must receive Boolean Tokens. The trueInput and falseInput ports may receive Tokens of any type. Because tokens are immutable, the same Token is sent to the output, rather than a copy.

Note this actor sends an output token every two iterations. Contrast this with BooleanSelect which sends an output token every iteration.

property.configure: Input for tokens on the false path. The port type can be any type.

property.configure: The output port. The type is at least the type of trueInput and falseInput.

property.name: description
property.configure: null

property.name: author
property.configure: Edward Lee

property.name: version
property.configure: null

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
The StringConstant actor outputs a string specified via the actor's value parameter.

Specifying strings with the StringConstant actor is convenient, as the actor does not require that strings be surrounded by quotes. The actor is often used to specify file paths, which can be selected using the Browse button available in the actor's parameters.

Specified string values can include references to parameters within scope (i.e., parameters defined at the same level of the hierarchy or higher).

NOTE: If using a PN Director, the 'firingCountLimit' parameter is often set to a finite integer (e.g. '1') so that the workflow will terminate.

property.name: port:output
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts a string constant specified by the value parameter.

property.name: port:trigger
property.configure: A multiport that has no declared type (in other words, the port can accept any data type: double, int, array, etc.) If the port is connected, the actor will not fire until the trigger port receives an input token. Connecting the port is optional, but useful when scheduling the actor to perform at a certain time.

property.name: prop:firingCountLimit
property.configure: The limit on the number of times the actor will fire. The default value is 'NONE', meaning there is no limit on the number of time the constant will be provided to the output port. Any integer can be provided as a value for this parameter.

property.name: prop:value
property.configure: The value produced by the actor. Specified strings do not require enclosing quotes. (To include a '$' sign in the string, enter '$$'.)

property.name: description
property.configure: It reads the content of a directory and creates an SoF

property.name: author
property.configure: ESO

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure: The SofCreator reads the contents of a directory and creates an SoF: the file category is based on the keyword PRO.CATG or REFLEX.CATG. If both are missing the Default Category is used.

property.name: port:data dir
property.configure: The input dir. If an empty string is provided the actor generates an empty SoF

property.name: port:sof out
property.configure: The output sof

property.name: prop:Filename Pattern
property.configure: a wildcard pattern representing the files to be included (e.g. *.fits)

property.name: prop:Default Category
property.configure: The default category to be used to classify FITS files if they do not possess any of the required keywords.

property.name: prop:Dataset name
property.configure: the dataset name of the output SoF

property.name: author
property.configure: ESO

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
The SofCombiner takes as input a number of set of files and combines them into one set of files that contains only the files whose purposes are present in all the input tokens. With this respect empty tokens are ignored and files with universal purpose are always collected.

For example, consider the following SoFs:

SoF1: File1(Purpose1), File2(Purpose2), File3(Purpose3)

SoF2: File4(Purpose2), File5(Purpose3), File6(Purpose4), File7(UNIVERSAL)

SoF3:

SoF4: File8(Purpose2), File9(Purpose5), File10(Purpose6)

SoF5: File11(Purpose2), File12(Purpose3), File13(Purpose7)

SoF6:

SoF7: File14(UNIVERSAL)

If SoF 1-3 are connected to sof in and the SoF 4-7 are connected to sof opt in, then the output SoF will be:

File2(Purpose2), File3(Purpose3)

File4(Purpose2), File5(Purpose3), File7(Purpose2,Purpose3)

File8(Purpose2)

File11(Purpose2), File12(Purpose3)

File14(Purpose2,Purpose3)

Note: all input multi ports that take SoF as input (e.g. in the RecipeExecuter) behave like the SofCombiner with no optional inputs

property.name: port:sof in opt
property.configure: The optional input sofs, these files are added to the output only if their purpose is present in one of the input SoFs

property.name: port:sof in
property.configure: The input sofs

property.name: port:sof out
property.configure: The combined sof

property.name: prop:IgnorePurpose
property.configure: if true, the input SoFs will be combined regardless of the purposes.

property.name: description
property.configure: null

property.name: author
property.configure: ESO

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
The FitsRouter sorts files based on their category: by default, all files are routed to the rejected directory, but the user can add an additional port and configure the actor to route particular files to the new port. The category is defined by the value of either HIERARCH.ESO.PRO.CATG (keyword added to the file by the pipeline recipes) or REFLEX.CATG (virtual keyword created by the DataOrganizer).

Basic Mode: create an output port named as a category (e.g.: FLAT), all files belonging to that category will be routed to that port.

Advanced Mode: create an output port named as you want (e.g.: MyPort), then create a string parameter whose name is the port name plus "_config" (e.g.: MyPort_config). This parameter can be a list of regular expressions separated by a comma or a space (you can mix both in the same parameter): each file matching at least one of them will be routed to this port.

If you want to define the minimum or maximum the number of files that are broadcasted to a port you can define a parameter whose name is the port name plus "_min_number" or "_max_number", respectively.

Note: one file can be routed to many ports, if no port fits it is routed to the rejected port.

property.name: port:in
property.configure: The input data

property.name: port:sof rejected
property.configure: The rejected SoF

property.name: description
property.configure: Identifies empty SoFs

property.name: author
property.configure: ESO

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure: IsSofEmpty emits a true token if the input soF is empty

property.name: port:is not empty
property.configure: true if the input is not empty

property.name: port:is empty
property.configure: true if the input is empty

property.name: port:sof in
property.configure: The input sof

property.name: description
property.configure: null

property.name: author
property.configure: Steve Neuendorffer

property.name: version
property.configure: null

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
The BooleanSwitch actor reads a value of any type, as well as a Boolean token that is used as a control. If the Boolean token is true, the actor outputs the received value to the trueOutput port; if the Boolean token is false, the actor outputs the received value to the falseOutput port. If the actor has never received a value on the control port, then the actor will output to the falseOutput port.

The actor only works under certain directors. It will not work under an SDF Director, but it will under a PN Director, for example.

property.name: port:input
property.configure: An input port that accepts tokens of any type.

property.name: port:falseOutput
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts the input token when the control is false.

property.name: port:trueOutput
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts the input token when the control is true.

property.name: port:control
property.configure: An input port that accepts a Boolean token used to select which output port (trueOutput or falseOutput) to broadcast.

property.name: description
property.configure: null

property.name: author
property.configure: Gang Zhou

property.name: version
property.configure: null

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
A type polymorphic select with boolean valued control for use in the DDF domain. In the first iteration, an input token at the control port is read and its value is noted. In the second iteration, if the control input read from the previous iteration is true, then an input token at the trueInput port is read and sent to the output. Likewise with a false control input and the falseInput port. It alternates between these two kinds of iterations until stopped. The control port must receive Boolean Tokens. The trueInput and falseInput ports may receive Tokens of any type. Because tokens are immutable, the same Token is sent to the output, rather than a copy.

Note this actor sends an output token every two iterations. Contrast this with BooleanSelect which sends an output token every iteration.

property.name: port:falseInput
property.configure: Input for tokens on the false path. The port type can be any type.

property.name: port:output
property.configure: The output port. The type is at least the type of trueInput and falseInput.

property.name: port:trueInput
property.configure: Input for tokens on the true path. The port type can be any type.

property.name: port:control
property.configure: Input that selects one of the other input ports. The type is boolean.

property.name: description
property.configure: null

property.name: author
property.configure: Edward Lee

property.name: version
property.configure: null

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
The StringConstant actor outputs a string specified via the actor's value parameter.

Specifying strings with the StringConstant actor is convenient, as the actor does not require that strings be surrounded by quotes. The actor is often used to specify file paths, which can be selected using the Browse button available in the actor's parameters.

Specified string values can include references to parameters within scope (i.e., parameters defined at the same level of the hierarchy or higher).

NOTE: If using a PN Director, the 'firingCountLimit' parameter is often set to a finite integer (e.g. '1') so that the workflow will terminate.

property.name: port:output
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts a string constant specified by the value parameter.

property.name: port:trigger
property.configure: A multiport that has no declared type (in other words, the port can accept any data type: double, int, array, etc.) If the port is connected, the actor will not fire until the trigger port receives an input token. Connecting the port is optional, but useful when scheduling the actor to perform at a certain time.

property.name: prop:firingCountLimit
property.configure: The limit on the number of times the actor will fire. The default value is 'NONE', meaning there is no limit on the number of time the constant will be provided to the output port. Any integer can be provided as a value for this parameter.

property.name: prop:value
property.configure: The value produced by the actor. Specified strings do not require enclosing quotes. (To include a '$' sign in the string, enter '$$'.)

property.name: description
property.configure: It reads the content of a directory and creates an SoF

property.name: author
property.configure: ESO

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure: The SofCreator reads the contents of a directory and creates an SoF: the file category is based on the keyword PRO.CATG or REFLEX.CATG. If both are missing the Default Category is used.

property.name: port:data dir
property.configure: The input dir. If an empty string is provided the actor generates an empty SoF

property.name: port:sof out
property.configure: The output sof

property.name: prop:Filename Pattern
property.configure: a wildcard pattern representing the files to be included (e.g. *.fits)

property.name: prop:Default Category
property.configure: The default category to be used to classify FITS files if they do not possess any of the required keywords.

property.name: prop:Dataset name
property.configure: the dataset name of the output SoF

property.name: description
property.configure: null

property.name: author
property.configure: Yuhong Xiong

property.name: version
property.configure: null

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
A Composite actor is an aggregation of actors. It may have a local director that is responsible for executing the contained actors. A Composite actor with a local director is called an opaque actor. Composite actors do not require a local director. Composite actors with no local director "inherit" the director from the containing workflow and are called non-opaque.

To create a composite actor, drag and drop the Composite actor onto the Workflow canvas. Right-click the actor and select Open Actor from the drop-down menu. A new Kepler application window will open for designing the composite.

property.name: description
property.configure: null

property.name: author
property.configure: Gang Zhou

property.name: version
property.configure: null

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
The dynamic dataflow (DDF) domain is a superset of the synchronous dataflow(SDF) and Boolean dataflow(BDF) domains. In the SDF domain, an actor consumes and produces a fixed number of tokens per firing. This static information makes possible compile-time scheduling. In the DDF domain, there are few constraints on the production and consumption behavior of actors, and the schedulers make no attempt to construct a compile-time schedule. Instead, each actor has a set of firing rules (patterns) and can be fired if one of them is satisfied, i.e., one particular firing pattern forms a prefix of sequences of unconsumed tokens at input ports. The canonical actors in the DDF domain include Select and Switch, which consume or produce tokens on different channels based on the token received from the control port. (In practice, use DDFSelect and DDFBooleanSelect in the DDF-specific library instead of Select and BooleanSelect in the regular FlowControl library; however, Switch and BooleanSwitch in the regular FlowControl library can be used in DDF domain.)

The dynamic scheduler implemented in this director fires all enabled and non-deferrable actors once in a basic iteration. A deferrable actor is one that will not help one of the downstream actors become enabled because that downstream actor either already has enough tokens on the channel connecting those two actors or is waiting for tokens on another channel. If no actor fires so far, which means there is no enabled and non-deferrable actor, then among all enabled and deferrable actors, this director fires those which have the smallest maximum number of tokens on their output channels which satisfy the demand of destination actors. If still no actor fires, then there is no enabled actor. A user can treat several such basic iterations as a single iteration by adding a parameter with name requiredFiringsPerIteration to an actor (which is often a sink actor or an actor directly connected to output port of the composite actor) and specifying the number of times this actor must be fired in a single iteration. If the value of the parameter runUntilDeadlockInOneIteration is a BooleanToken with value true, one single iteration consists of repeating the basic iteration until deadlock is reached (thus overriding the previous definition of one iteration), which is the status of the model where all active actors under the control of this director are unable to fire because their firing rules are not satisfied. However, they may be able to fire again during next iteration when tokens are transferred in from an outside domain. Note runUntilDeadlockInOneIteration can be set to true only when this director is not on the top level.

The algorithm implementing one basic iteration goes like this: 

            E = set of enabled actors
            D = set of deferrable enabled actors
One basic(default) iteration consists of: 
            if (E\D != empty set) {
            fire (E\D)
            } else if (D != empty set) {
            fire minimax(D)
            } else {
            declare deadlock
            }
The function "minimax(D)" returns a subset of D with the smallest maximum number of tokens on their output channels which satisfy the demand of destination actors.

Note that any SDF model can be run with a DDF Director. However, the notion of iteration is different. One could try to imitate the SDF iteration in the DDF domain by controlling the number of firings in one iteration for some actors, such as requiring a plotter to plot a fixed number of points in each iteration.

In the DDF domain, the firing rule of any actor is specified by the token consumption rates of its input ports. A general DDF actor could change the consumption rates of its input ports after each firing of this actor. For multiports, an array token could be used to specify different rates for different channels connected to the same multiport. Note that in SDF, all channels connected to the same multiport have the same rate.

Based on DDFSimpleSched in Ptolemy Classic, by Edward Lee. See E. A. Lee et al., "The Almagest," documentation for Ptolemy Classic, Vol. 1, Chapter 7, 1997.

property.name: prop:iterations
property.configure: Specify the number of times a workflow is iterated. By default, this parameter is set to "0". Note that "0" does not mean "no iterations." Rather, "0" means that the workflow will iterate forever. Values greater than zero specify the actual number of times the director should execute the entire workflow.

property.name: prop:maximumReceiverCapacity
property.configure: A Parameter representing the maximum capacity of each receiver controlled by this director. This is an integer that defaults to 0, which means the queue in each receiver is unbounded. To specify bounded queues, set this to a positive integer.

property.name: prop:runUntilDeadlockInOneIteration
property.configure: A parameter indicating whether one iteration consists of repeated basic iterations until deadlock. If this parameter is true, the model will be executed until deadlock in one iteration. The default value is a BooleanToken with the value false. It cannot be set to true if this director is at the top level.

property.name: text
property.value: If the master calibration is present, then it is broadcasted. Otherwise the files are sent to the upper branch

property.name: prop:fontFamily
property.configure: The font face. Select a font from the drop-down menu. The default is "SansSerif".

property.name: prop:italic
property.configure: Select to indicate that the type should be italics. By default, type will not be italicized.

property.name: prop:bold
property.configure: Select to indicate that the type should be bold. By default, type will not be bold.

property.name: prop:textColor
property.configure: The font color. Specify a string representing an array of four elements: red, green, blue, and alpha, where alpha is transparency. The default is an opaque black, {0.0, 0.0, 0.0, 1.0}

property.name: prop:textSize
property.configure: The font size. Select an integer from the drop-down menu or specify a new size by typing it directly into the value field. The default is 14.

property.name: prop:text
property.configure: The text of the annotation.

property.name: text
property.value: If the raw category that triggers the recipe is present, then the recipeExecuter is triggered else an empty sof is brodcasted

property.name: description
property.configure: null

property.name: author
property.configure: Edward A. Lee

property.name: version
property.configure: null

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure: Use the Annotation attribute to annotate a workflow. Double-click the attribute to customize the content, font size, color, and basic formatting (bold and italics).

property.configure: The font face. Select a font from the drop-down menu. The default is "SansSerif".

property.configure: Select to indicate that the type should be italics. By default, type will not be italicized.

property.name: Input Files Category
property.value: ARC, MASTER_BIAS, MASTER_DARK, MASTER_FLAT, TRACE_TABLE, LINE_CATALOG, BADPIX_TABLE, NONLINEARITY_GAIN

property.name: Output Files Category
property.value: WAVECAL_TABLE, WAVECAL_RESIDUALS, ARC_RED_LAMP, ARC_RED, ARC_RESAMPLED, WAVE_MAP

property.name: File Purpose Processing
property.value: Strip last

property.name: description
property.configure: null

property.name: author
property.configure: null

property.name: version
property.configure: null

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
The RecipeExecuter executes one CPL recipe. The recipe can be chosen only when you instantiate the component: at the moment the user is presented with a list of the available recipes (the output of esorex --recipes). After the user selects the recipe the actor queries EsoRex for the recipe parameters and adds them to the actor. Each parameter is set to the default value: if the user wants to change any of the parameters then he can enter his own value or he can write the special value PORT, in which case the value is taken from the input port SoP.

The actor has three modes: Run, Skip and Disabled

Note: since this actor has very different behaviour depending on the pipeline recipe to which it is associated, it is not present in the left hand side actor list, and instead it must be instantiated from the menu.

property.name: port:sop in
property.configure: the recipe input parameters

property.name: port:rejected outputs
property.configure: the outputs not matching any of the output categories

property.name: port:logs
property.configure: the logs generated by EsoRex, empty if lazy mode is triggered

property.name: port:rejected inputs
property.configure: the inputs not matching any of the input categories

property.name: port:warnings
property.configure: the warnings generated by EsoRex, empty if lazy mode is triggered

property.name: port:sof in
property.configure: the input files

property.name: port:sof out
property.configure: the output files

property.name: port:errors
property.configure: the errors generated by EsoRex, empty if lazy mode is triggered

property.name: port:sop out
property.configure: the parameters used in the last execution of the recipe

property.name: prop:Lazy Mode
property.configure: if true then the actor will check whether the pipeline recipe has already been executed with the same input files and with the same recipe parameters. If this is the case then the recipe will not be executed, and instead the previously generated products (which are the same as those that would have been generated if the recipe were executed, except for a timestamp) will be broadcast to the output port.

property.name: prop:EsoRex default args
property.configure: additional parameters passed to EsoRex

property.name: prop:recipe
property.configure: the selected pipeline recipe (cannot be changed)

property.name: prop:Products Dir
property.configure: the directory where the products will be created

property.name: prop:File Purpose Processing
property.configure:
how the purpose of the input files will be sent to the output:

Do nothing: leave the input purpose unmodified

Strip last: remove the last section of the input purpose, if there is only one section set the purpose to universal. This is the default mode, and it means that the actor has completed a reduction step and removes it from the purpose chain

Set to universal: set the output purpose to universal

property.name: prop:recipe_param_19
property.configure: Parameter name: wavemap. Default value:false

property.name: prop:recipe_param_18
property.configure: Parameter name: resample. Default value:false

property.name: prop:recipe_param_17
property.configure: Parameter name: saveimages. Default value:false

property.name: prop:Allow empty inputs
property.configure: if true then an empty sof on the input port will be broadcast to the output without executing the recipe

property.name: prop:recipe_param_16
property.configure: Parameter name: fitweighting. Default value:cerrscatter

property.name: prop:mode
property.configure:
Run: the recipe will be executed (see lazy mode)

Skip: the inputs are broadcast to the output with the following modifications: input files will be filtered according to input and output tags and recipe parameters will be filtered based on the recipe and whether the parameter is set to PORT

Disabled: the recipe is not executed and an empty SoF is generated on the output port

property.name: prop:Pause after execution
property.configure: if true then the execution is paused after the execution of the recipe

property.name: prop:recipe_param_15
property.configure: Parameter name: fitsigma. Default value:-1

property.name: prop:recipe_param_14
property.configure: Parameter name: residuals. Default value:false

property.name: prop:recipe_param_13
property.configure: Parameter name: linesigma. Default value:-1

property.name: prop:recipe_param_12
property.configure: Parameter name: yorder. Default value:6

property.name: prop:recipe_param_11
property.configure: Parameter name: xorder. Default value:2

property.name: prop:recipe_param_10
property.configure: Parameter name: tolerance. Default value:0.1

property.name: prop:Pause before execution
property.configure: if true then the execution is paused just before executing the recipe

property.name: prop:recipe_param_9
property.configure: Parameter name: dres. Default value:0.05

property.name: prop:recipe_param_8
property.configure: Parameter name: sigma. Default value:1

property.name: prop:recipe_param_7
property.configure: Parameter name: lampwise. Default value:true

property.name: prop:recipe_param_6
property.configure: Parameter name: combine. Default value:sigclip

property.name: prop:recipe_param_5
property.configure: Parameter name: ovscignore. Default value:3

property.name: prop:recipe_param_4
property.configure: Parameter name: ovscsigma. Default value:30

property.name: prop:recipe_param_3
property.configure: Parameter name: ovscreject. Default value:dcr

property.name: prop:recipe_param_2
property.configure: Parameter name: overscan. Default value:vpoly

property.name: prop:recipe_param_1
property.configure: Parameter name: nifu. Default value:0

property.name: prop:Logs Dir
property.configure: the directory where the EsoRex logs will be saved

property.name: prop:Input Files Category
property.configure: a list of file categories separated by a comma or a space: only input files belonging to one of these categories will be passed to the recipe

property.name: prop:Recipe Failure Mode
property.configure:
it specifies the behavior of the actor if the recipe fails

Stop: the actor produces an error message and the workflows stops. This is the default

Continue: the actor outputs an empty SoF

Ask: the actor pops up a window and asks the user whether he wants to continue or stop the execution

property.name: prop:Output Files Category
property.configure: a list of file categories separated by a comma or a space: only products belonging to one of these categories will be broadcast to the output port

property.name: prop:Bookkeeping Dir
property.configure: the directory the recipe will use as a working directory

property.name: prop:recipe_param_20
property.configure: Parameter name: merge. Default value:false

property.name: prop:Clean Temporary Directories
property.configure: if true, the temporary directories (where the logs, the final and the temporary products of the recipe are created) are cleaned before the execution
